On Sep 28, 2012, at 2:57 PM, Ruben Verborgh wrote:

>> It invalidates the =
term 'entry point' entirely. If you are allowed to
>> bookmark any resource=
 (posts, comments, etc) then any resource is an
>> entry point, at which po=
int stating that your blog index is an entry
>> point is meaningless.
> 
> =
But what=92s the point then of giving those non-entry resources a URI?
> 
>=
 I=92d argue that the definition of =93entry point=94 depends on the client=
.
> If the client never visited the blog, the index is the only entry point=
.
> If it has, then other entry points come available.

Yep - any URI can b=
e an entry point if the client wants to.

Some URIs make better ones than o=
thers, of course.

Bute surely, any product-URI at Amazon is as good to ent=
er a purchase as is the Amazon homepage.

Jan
